thread.title_full: BOE official: Rate hike 'sooner rather than later' - MarketWatch

author: Jon Sindreu
title: BOE official: Rate hike 'sooner rather than later' - MarketWatch
text:
The Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates sooner rather than later, one of the central bank's policymakers said Friday, a stance that goes against market expectations that borrowing costs will stay at record-low levels until late-2016 or even 2017.
In a speech to businesspeople in the city of Brighton, in southern England, BOE official Kristin Forbes said the "doom and gloom sentiment" for emerging markets had been overstated.
"The news on the international economy has not caused me to adjust my prior expectations that the next move in U.K. interest rates will be up and that it will occur sooner rather than later," she said, according to a text of her remarks, released ahead of the speech.
Steep losses in the Shanghai stock market in August rattled policymakers and analysts around the world, who fear a marked slowdown in the Chinese economy could critically hurt emerging markets and have a knock on effect on global activity.
In its September policy meeting, the U.S. Federal Reserve kept interest rates at zero, despite earlier expectations by investors of a small increase, a sign that officials were worried about a volatile world economy. Most economists believe the Bank of England will wait for the Fed to move before nudging up borrowing costs in the U.K., since tightening policy before the U.S. would likely appreciate the pound further--a strength that has already hampered British exports.
However, officials at the BOE have so far shrugged off concerns about emerging economies, due to the small exposure of U.K. companies to those markets. During her speech Friday, Ms. Forbes suggested "the U.K. economy is unlikely to be immune" to a global slowdown, and said many emerging nations are making "beneficial transitions toward more sustainable and balanced growth."
Despite this hawkish turn, Ms. Forbes was at one point is considered a dovish member of the Bank of England's rate-setting panel, the Monetary Policy Committee, and since her appointment in July last year has never voted to increase interest rates from their current record-low 0.5% level--where they have stayed for over six years.
Her views are consistent with comments made by most other BOE officials, who have so far signaled interest rates are likely to start rising around the beginning of next year. But investors are gloomier about Britain's economic prospects and are expecting a rate increase by late-2016 or even 2017.
Recent economic data has suggested the U.K. economy slowed during the third quarter of the year, while annual inflation was negative in September--far from the central bank's 2% target in the medium term. While such figures might suggest policymakers still have much wiggle room to leave rates low without fear of stoking inflation, strong gains in unemployment and wages could also indicate the economy is ready for a small increase in borrowing costs.
